# _Catechism of a Revolutionary_

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to navigation Jump to search

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Nechayev.png/200px-
Nechayev.png)](/wiki/File:Nechayev.png)

[](/wiki/File:Nechayev.png "Enlarge")

Anarchist and nihilist revolutionary [Sergey Nechayev](/wiki/Sergey_Nechayev
"Sergey Nechayev") (1847–1882)

The _**Catechism of a Revolutionary**_ refers to a [manifesto](/wiki/Manifesto
"Manifesto") written by Russian revolutionary [Sergey
Nechayev](/wiki/Sergey_Nechayev "Sergey Nechayev") between April and August
1869.

## Contents

  * 1 The Manifesto
  * 2 Criticism
  * 3 See also
  * 4 Footnotes
  * 5 References
  * 6 External links

## The
Manifesto[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Catechism_of_a_Revolutionary&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: The Manifesto")]

The manifesto is a manual for the formation of secret societies.

It is debated how much input [Mikhail Bakunin](/wiki/Mikhail_Bakunin "Mikhail
Bakunin") had or if it is solely the work of Nechayev.[1] The work called for
total devotion to a revolutionary lifestyle.[2] Its publication in the
_Government Herald_ in July 1871 as the manifesto of the Narodnaya Rasprava
secret society ("Общество народной расправы") was one of the most dramatic
events of Nechayev's revolutionary life,[3][4][5] through its words and the
actions it inspired establishing Nechayev's importance for the [Nihilist
movement](/wiki/Nihilist_movement "Nihilist movement").[6] The _Catechism_ is
divided into two sections; General Rules of the Organisation and Rules of
Conduct of Revolutionaries, 22 and 26 paragraphs long respectively;[4]
abridged versions were published as excerpts in the [anarchist
periodicals](/wiki/Anarchist_periodicals "Anarchist periodicals")
_[Freiheit](/wiki/Freiheit_\(1879\) "Freiheit \(1879\)")_ and _[The
Alarm](/wiki/The_Alarm_\(newspaper\) "The Alarm \(newspaper\)")_.[7]

The most radical document of its age,[8] the _Catechism_ outlined the authors'
revolutionary [Jacobin](/wiki/Jacobin_\(politics\) "Jacobin \(politics\)")
program of organisation and discipline, a program that became the backbone of
the radical movement in Russia. The [revolutionary](/wiki/Revolutionary
"Revolutionary") is portrayed in the _Catechism_ as an amoral avenging angel,
an expendable resource in the service of the revolution,[6] committed to any
crime or treachery necessary to effect the downfall of the prevailing
order.[4]

> The revolutionary is a doomed man. He has no private interests, no affairs,
> sentiments, ties, property nor even a name of his own. His entire being is
> devoured by one purpose, one thought, one passion - the revolution. Heart
> and soul, not merely by word but by deed, he has severed every link with the
> social order and with the entire civilized world; with the laws, good
> manners, conventions, and morality of that world. He is its merciless enemy
> and continues to inhabit it with only one purpose - to destroy it. –
>
> —  _Catechism of a Revolutionary_ , opening lines.[7]

##
Criticism[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Catechism_of_a_Revolutionary&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Criticism")]

[Critics of anarchism](/wiki/Criticism_of_anarchism "Criticism of anarchism")
argue that the _Catechism_ reflects the innately violent and
[nihilistic](/wiki/Nihilism "Nihilism") nature of the philosophy.[9] Scholar
[Michael Allen Gillespie](/wiki/Michael_Allen_Gillespie "Michael Allen
Gillespie") has hailed the _Catechism_ as "a pre-eminent expression of the
doctrine of freedom and negation" that arose in the
[Fichtean](/wiki/Johann_Gottlieb_Fichte "Johann Gottlieb Fichte") notion of
the "Absolute I" that had been concealed in [Left
Hegelianism](/wiki/Left_Hegelianism "Left Hegelianism").[6] Prominent [Black
Panther](/wiki/Black_Panther_Party "Black Panther Party") of the 20th century
[Eldridge Cleaver](/wiki/Eldridge_Cleaver "Eldridge Cleaver") adopted the
_Catechism_ as a "revolutionary bible", incorporating it into his daily life
to the extent that he employed, in his words, "tactics of ruthlessness in my
dealings with everyone with whom I came into contact".[10] The ideas and
sentiments in the work had been in part previously aired by
[Zaichnevsky](/w/index.php?title=Zaichnevsky&action=edit&redlink=1
"Zaichnevsky \(page does not exist\)") and [Nikolai
Ishutin](/wiki/Nikolai_Ishutin "Nikolai Ishutin") in Russia, and by
[Carbonari](/wiki/Carbonari "Carbonari") and [Young
Italy](/wiki/Young_Italy_\(historical\) "Young Italy \(historical\)") in the
West.[11]

The journal _Cahiers du monde russe et soviétique_ published a letter from
Bakunin to Nechayev, in which Bakunin wrote, "You remember how you were angry
with me, when I called you [abrek](/wiki/Abrek "Abrek") and called your
Catechism the Catechism of abreks?"[12]
